text: I'm late to this discussion, but do you think ungating content can work for an enterprise SaaS B2B business with a long sales cycle? I guess I wonder if it works better for a SaaS company that can offer something like a free product trial for easy email capture, because then you still have that option. If we tried ungating, our main source of email capture would become demo requests and probably webinars since it's harder to ungate reg for those. BUT, ungating might start to pay off in the long run because you'd be letting your buyers educate themselves much more easily before they make the leap to request a demo. (BUT then it is harder to nurture those buyers when you don't know who they are). Anyways, this is becoming a conversation with myself... :wink: What am I missing in my thought process? I'd really like to ungate more, but does it work when you think about the full buyer's journey?

root.text: hello all. I was having a nerdy content discussion today, and a CEO of a new startup in my network mentioned that he thinks that the white paper/long-form gated content is dead. He said ‘nobody downloads these any more’. I still see value in them as a concept — but am I just a fuddy duddy? Would love to hear your thoughts, whether pro/con  — and what your approach is :slightly_smiling_face:

BUT, ungating might start to pay off in the long run because you'd be letting your buyers educate themselves much more easily before they make the leap to request a demo. (BUT then it is harder to nurture those buyers when you don't know who they are). Anyways, this is becoming a conversation with myself...
What am I missing in my thought process? I'd really like to ungate more, but does it work when you think about the full buyer's journey?

text: We use bylines from our staff because of Google's E-A-T framework - we want readers and Google to know that the content we put out is expert-approved. That being said, we do not publish the piece under bylines without that internal staff member's review and approval. That also gives me a layer of comfort knowing that someone who knows their stuff has reviewed what we're saying!

text:
<@UMQASRN1W> We’ve been testing gated, then ungating it later on. B2B services company btw. This is mainly because our paid team uses content a lot to gather leads, so they’re hungry for more gated stuff! Then after a while once it’s kinda exhausted and we have something new for them, so we open it up.

And actually, if it’s like a big guide, we are putting it into a LP and letting it start to rank organically for a while before we lift the gates. So, some folks may stumble on that page in the first few months by chance without having to ever put in an email :nerd_face:

Not sure if this is the best tactic, but so far it’s been working for us.

Another thing we’ve tried a bit is having something gated, but creating an un-gated “lite” version. So people can still get value from it, and if they want more, they can fill in the form.

elements.text:

And actually, if it’s like a big guide, we are putting it into a LP and letting it start to rank organically for a while before we lift the gates. So, some folks may stumble on that page in the first few months by chance without having to ever put in an email

Not sure if this is the best tactic, but so far it’s been working for us.

Another thing we’ve tried a bit is having something gated, but creating an un-gated “lite” version. So people can still get value from it, and if they want more, they can fill in the form.

text:
<@ULKUFTFPW> I recently did something similar because of an M&A. Our parent company acquired a smaller company with great traffic/DA (much higher than the parent).

We migrated all the content with substantial traffic/links/relevance to the parent site and did a ton of 301s and internal link updating. Traffic was 1:1 for the first month, declined about 20%, and now is starting to flatten finally. We haven't reached Brendan's Phase 4 yet, but I'm hopeful :crossed_fingers:

elements.text:

We migrated all the content with substantial traffic/links/relevance to the parent site and did a ton of 301s and internal link updating. Traffic was 1:1 for the first month, declined about 20%, and now is starting to flatten finally. We haven't reached Brendan's Phase 4 yet, but I'm hopeful

text: <@U01G7PRL3HQ> When you say 1:1, do you mean that you saw the traffic from the new site transfer over or that your traffic was the same as it was before the migration?
